text: ARIA-AI: In manufacturing, AI is used to analyze data from machinery such as vibration, temperature, and acoustic readings. This analysis allows for predictive maintenance and process optimization, enabling companies to forecast potential failures days in advance. As a result, AI-driven maintenance platforms have been shown to reduce downtime, improve safety, and lower spare-parts inventory costs. For example, a South Korean automotive plant reported a 40% decrease in unscheduled maintenance events using an AI-driven platform. Over-reliance on technology vendors without internal capability building. 2. Lack of executive sponsorship or alignment between IT and business units. 3. Insufficient data quality control leading to biased or unreliable AI outputs. 4. Cyber-security vulnerabilities introduced by rapid cloud migration. These obstacles can be addressed through a structured maturity model that progresses from digital awareness to full operational excellence, as outlined in the subsequent sections. Consumer Expectations: Hyper-personalization has become a baseline requirement; customers expect products and services tailored to their preferences in real time. 3. Regulatory Shifts: Data-privacy laws such as GDPR, CCPA, and Korea‚Äôs PIPA require organizations to implement rigorous data-management frameworks. 4. Technological Convergence: The overlap between AI, IoT, and blockchain is creating new business models‚Äîfrom predictive maintenance in manufacturing to tokenized digital assets in finance. These factors are mentioned in the excerpt [3.2 Economic Drivers] as driving forces behind the accelerating pace of digital transformation worldwide.
